case_name: Sheel Chandra (Hindu undivided family) v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Civil Appeal No.123 of 1957 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.123 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated May 12, 1955 of Punjab High Court in Civil Reference No.17/1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated May 12, 1955, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Reference No. 17/1953.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 26, 1960 by Kapur J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. April 26. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-

facts.text: Appellant is Hindu undivided family with Sheel Chandra as Karta.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the assessee-a Hindu undivided family-with Sheel Chandra as its Karta and the respondent is the Commissioner of Income- tax.

facts.text: Appeal relates to assessment year 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal relates to the assessment year 1951-52.

facts.text: Adishwar Lal, father of Sheel Chandra, died on April 16, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Their father, Adishwar La, upto his death on April 16, 1950, was the Treasurer of several branches of the Central Bank of India

facts.text: Adishwar Lal was Treasurer of several branches of Central Bank of India until his death.

anchor.surface_text: Their father, Adishwar La, upto his death on April 16, 1950, was the Treasurer of several branches of the Central Bank of India  which in the judgment will be referred to as the Bank .

facts.text: During father's lifetime, Sheel Chandra employed as Overseer in the Bank on salary of Rs. 400 per month.

anchor.surface_text: During his fathers lifetime Sheel Chandra was employed as an Overseer in the Bank on a salary of Rs. 400 a month.

facts.text: Sheel Chandra appointed Treasurer of Bank at Delhi and sixteen other branches.

anchor.surface_text: Sheel Chandra was appointed Treasurer of the Bank at Delhi and sixteen other branches of the Bank.

facts.text: Security furnished to Bank: title deeds of immovable properties in Chandni Chowk, Delhi, and GOI securities worth Rs.75,000 belonging to HUF.

anchor.surface_text: As Treasurer he furnished security to the Bank of certain properties of the Hindu undivided family, which companysisted of title deeds of immovable properties in Chandni Chowk, Delhi, and Government of India securities of the value of Rs. 75,000.

facts.text: HUF owns considerable property, income from house property Rs.50,000 per annum, stocks, shares, GOI securities.

anchor.surface_text: The Hindu undivided family owns companysiderable property. Its income from house property alone is Rs. 50,000 per annum and it owns stocks, shares and Government securities also of companysiderable value.

facts.text: Sheel Chandra received Rs.23,286 from Bank in the year of account as Treasurer.

anchor.surface_text: As Treasurer Sheel Chandra received in the year of account from the Bank a sum of Rs. 23,286

facts.text: Income-tax Authorities held Rs.23,286 as income of HUF and taxed it as such.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Authorities held this sum to be the latter and taxed it as such.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld that emoluments are profits of business of HUF because security from joint family properties.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal in upholding this view held that on a proper companystruction of the written agreement between Sheel Chandra and the Bank, the emoluments received by the Treasurer were profits and gains of business and it further held that as the security furnished by Sheel Chandra came out of the joint family proper. ties,

facts.text: Tribunal referred two questions to High Court under s.66(1) at instance of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the appellant the Tribunal referred under s. 66 1  the following two questions to the High Court- Whether in the facts and circumstances of the case and on a true companystruction of the agreement between the Central Bank of India and Sheel Chandra the salary and other emoluments

facts.text: First question: Whether emoluments assessable as salary or profits and gains of business.

anchor.surface_text: Whether in the facts and circumstances of the case and on a true companystruction of the agreement between the Central Bank of India and Sheel Chandra the salary and other emoluments received by Sheel Chandra as Treasurer of the said Bank are assessable under the head salary or under the head Profits and gains of business.

facts.text: Second question: Whether emoluments rightly assessed in hands of HUF.

anchor.surface_text: Whether in the facts and circumstances of the case, Sheel Chandras emoluments as Treasurer of the Central Bank of India Ltd. were rightly assessed in the hands of the Hindu undivided family of which he is the Karta.

facts.text: High Court answered both questions against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Both questions were answered against the appellant.

facts.text: High Court held relationship employer-independent contractor, not master-servant; emoluments profits of business.

anchor.surface_text: On a companysideration of the various clauses of the agreement between Sheel Chandra and the Bank, the High Court held that the relationship between them was number one of master and servant but that of an employer and independent companytractor and therefore the emoluments received by Sheel Chandra as Treasurer were number salary but profits and gains of business.

facts.text: High Court held emoluments income of HUF because appointed due to father's position and HUF security.

anchor.surface_text: As to the second question the High Court was of the opinion that the emoluments were the income of the Hindu undivided family because Sheel Chandra was number appointed Treasurer on account of any personal qualification but he was appointed because  a  his father was a Treasurer of the Bank before him and  b  he had furnished substantial security which was part of the property of the Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: Agreement between Sheel Chandra and Bank dated September 19, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The nature of the employment of Sheel Chandra has to be gathered from the agreement dated September 19, 1950, between him and the Bank.

facts.text: Appointment as Treasurer effective from April 16, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The appointment took effect from April 16, 1950.

facts.text: Sheel Chandra paid salary of Rs.1,750 per mensem for all branches.

anchor.surface_text: Sheel Chandra was paid a salary of Rs. 1,750 per mensem for all the branches he was employed in.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Sheel Chandra was servant of Bank, emoluments salary under s.7, not business under s.10.

anchor.surface_text: What we have to see is the effect of the agreement as a whole and taking the various clauses together it must be held that Sheel Chandra, the Treasurer, was a servant of the Bank.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds salary is individual income of Sheel Chandra, not HUF.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the judgment of the High Court was erroneous on both questions which were referred to it and they should both have been decided in favour of the appellant. The emoluments received by Sheel Chandra were in the nature of salary

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow this appeal and set aside the judgment and order of the High Court.

facts.text: No detriment to family property for Sheel Chandra's appointment.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberhing to show that Sheel Chandra had received any particular training at the expense of the family funds or his appointment was the result of any outlay or expenditure of or detriment to the family property.

facts.text: Appellant contends Sheel Chandra was servant based on salary, termination, control.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant companytended that the various provisions of the agreement showed that Sheel Chandra was a servant of the Bank and number an independent companytractor.

facts.text: Respondent contends Sheel Chandra carrying on business by supplying staff, guaranteeing fidelity.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention on behalf of the respondent on the other hand was that the agreement showed that Sheel Chandra was carrying on a business in that he was supplying cashiers and other members of the Cash Department Staff for a monetary company- sideration.

facts.text: HUF consists of Sheel Chandra and his younger brother.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, a Hindu undivided family, companysisted of Sheel Chandra and his Younger brother.
under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act which was answered in favour of the Commissioner of Income-tax.

arguments.claim: Sheel Chandra was a servant of the Bank and not an independent contractor, based on monthly salary, termination rights, duty to follow directions, liability for loss.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant contended that the various provisions of the agreement showed that Sheel Chandra was a servant of the Bank and not an independent contractor. He laid particular emphasis on the fact that he was appointed a Treasurer on a monthly salary and his services could be terminated forthwith in certain circumstances.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: argued on behalf of the respondent that because he had lodged joint family property by way of security his earnings as Treasurer became a part of the

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreement as whole shows servant relationship via control, supervision, integral work.

arguments.claim: Sheel Chandra was carrying on a business by supplying cashiers and Cash Department Staff for consideration, guaranteeing fidelity like insurance.

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the respondent on the other hand was that the agreement showed that Sheel Chandra was carrying on a business in that he was supplying cashiers and other members of the Cash Department Staff for a monetary consideration. He guaranteed their fidelity which was an insurance undertaken by him.

arguments.court_reasoning: Duties peculiar to Treasurer employment; control and supervision by Bank indicate servant.

arguments.claim: Emoluments are profits and gains of business per agreement construction; part of HUF income as security from joint property means not without detriment.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal in upholding this view held that on a proper construction of the written agreement between Sheel Chandra and the Bank, the emoluments received by the Treasurer were profits and gains of business and it further held that as the security furnished by Sheel Chandra came out of the joint family properties,

arguments.court_reasoning: Servant relationship; salary under s.7; no detriment to family property.

arguments.claim: Relationship is employer-independent contractor per agreement clauses, so emoluments profits of business not salary.

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of the various clauses of the agreement between Sheel Chandra and the Bank, the High Court held that the relationship between them was not one of master and servant but that of an employer and independent contractor and therefore the emoluments received by Sheel Chandra as Treasurer were not salary but profits and gains of business.

arguments.court_reasoning: Control test, integration, indicia show servant.

arguments.claim: Emoluments income of HUF as Sheel Chandra appointed not for personal qualification but due to father's prior position and HUF security.

anchor.surface_text: As to the second question the High Court was of the opinion that the emoluments were the income of the Hindu undivided family because Sheel Chandra was not appointed Treasurer on account of any personal qualification but he was appointed because (a) his father was a Treasurer of the Bank before him and (b) he had furnished substantial security which was part of the property of the Hindu undivided family.

arguments.court_reasoning: Personal fitness from experience; no detriment, training, or outlay from family funds.

arguments.claim: Control test: master directs what and how; distinguishes independent contractor; applies to facts showing Bank control.

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to lay down any one test to distinguish the relationship of master and servant from that of an employer and independent contractor. In many cases the test laid down is that in the case of master and servant the master can order or require what is to be done and how it is to be done but in the case of an independent contractor an employer can only say what is to be done but not how it shall be done.

arguments.claim: Integration test from Cassidy: Treasurer's work integral part of Bank's business, not accessory.

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out in Cassidy v. Ministry of Health that in the case of contract of service a man is employed as part of the business, and his work is done as an integral part of the business whereas under a contract for services the contractor is not integrated into the business but is only accessory to it.

arguments.claim: Indicia of service contract: selection, wages, control of method, suspension/dismissal rights present.

anchor.surface_text: In certain cases it has been laid down that the indicia of a contract of service are (a) the masters power of selection of the servant (b) the payment of wages or other remunerations (c) the masters right to control the method of doing the work and (d) the masters right of suspension or dismissal.

arguments.claim: Due control and supervision test from Dharangadhara: nature of work shows Bank control over Treasurer and staff.

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwati, J., in Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra said that in all cases the correct method of approach is whether having regard to the nature of work there was due control and supervision by the employer.

arguments.claim: Overall agreement effect: various clauses together show servant relationship.

anchor.surface_text: What we have to see is the effect of the agreement as a whole and taking the various clauses together it must be held that Sheel Chandra, the Treasurer, was a servant of the Bank.

arguments.claim: Distinguish K.P. Bhargava: different contract terms, commission agency not employment.

anchor.surface_text: K. P. Bhargava v. The Commissioner of Income-Tax, U. P. was the case of a Treasurer of the Central Bank of India at Agra. There he was paid a salary of Rs. 100 and a commission for his work as a Guarantee Commission Agent but the terms of the contract were different and that was clearly a case of a Guarantee Commission Agency.

arguments.claim: Distinguish Lala Jeewan Lal: commission agency under EPT Act, different circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: Lala Jeewan Lal v. Commissioner of Income-tax was also a case of commission agency and in the peculiar circumstances of that case it was held to be business within s. 2(5) of the Excess Profits Tax Act.

arguments.claim: Emoluments assessable as salary under s.7 not business profits under s.10.

anchor.surface_text: The emoluments received by Sheel Chandra were in the nature of salary and therefore assessable under s. 7 of the Income-tax Act and not under s. 10 of the Act as profits and gains of business

arguments.claim: Salary is individual income of Sheel Chandra, not HUF; no detriment, outlay, training from family funds; security alone insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing to show that Sheel Chandra had received any particular training at the expense of the family funds or his appointment was the result of any outlay or expenditure of or detriment to the family property.

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguishes Gokul Chand (expenditure for qualifications); no risk/detriment as in cases.

arguments.claim: Joint family property as security creates risk/detriment per Gokul Chand, making earnings HUF income.

anchor.surface_text: But it was argued on behalf of the respondent that because he had lodged joint family property by way of security his earnings as Treasurer became a part of the income of the Hindu undivided family for the reason that the acquisition was not without risk to the family estate. He relied on Gokul Chand v. Firm Hukum Chand Nath Mal

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of which was the subject matter of dispute but the respondents were number able to refer to any decision in which it was held that the mere fact of gi

arguments.court_reasoning: Risk/detriment in Gokul Chand context of expenditure for training; security alone not sufficient; no cases hold so.

arguments.claim: Distinguish Kalu Babu Lal Chand for HUF: there business acquired with family funds, company financed by family, MD office assignable.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondent also relied on Commissioner of Income-tax v. Kalu Babu Lal Chand where the Managing Directors remuneration was held to be the income of a joint family to be assessed as such in its hands. That case is distinguishable.

arguments.court_reasoning: Facts different: no family financing or business acquisition here.

arguments.claim: Shivanandan Sharma similar: agreement of service not agency.

anchor.surface_text: There was an agreement with very similar clauses in Shivanandan Sharma v. The Punjab National Bank Ltd. and it was held to be an agreement of service and not of agency.

holdings.text: Sheel Chandra, the Treasurer, was a servant of the Bank.

anchor.surface_text: What we have to see is the effect of the agreement as a whole and taking the various clauses together it must be held that Sheel Chandra, the Treasurer, was a servant of the Bank.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement interpreted as whole; control/supervision test, integration test, indicia of service contract, and due control over nature of work applied from precedents like Dharangadhara, Cassidy, Short.

holdings.text: The emoluments received by Sheel Chandra were in the nature of salary and therefore assessable under s. 7 of the Income-tax Act and not under s. 10 of the Act as profits and gains of business.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the judgment of the High Court was erroneous on both questions which were referred to it and they should both have been decided in favour of the appellant. The emoluments received by Sheel Chandra were in the nature of salary and therefore assessable under s. 7 of the Income- tax Act and not under s. 10

holdings.reasoning_summary: Servant status determines salary head u/s.7; rejects business profits u/s.10 based on employment relationship.

holdings.text: the salary was the income of the individual, i.e., Sheel Chandra and not the income of the Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: of the Act as profits and gains of business and the salary was the income of the individual, i.e., Sheel Chandra and not the income of the Hindu undivided family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No detriment, outlay, expenditure, or training from family funds; mere security insufficient per HUF doctrine; distinguishes Gokul Chand, Kalu Babu.

holdings.text: There is nothing to show that Sheel Chandra had received any particular training at the expense of the family funds or his appointment was the result of any outlay or expenditure of or detriment to the family property.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing to show that Sheel Chandra had received any particular training at the expense of the family funds or his appointment was the result of any outlay or expenditure of or detriment to the family property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Personal fitness from experience; no family investment or risk beyond security, which alone does not qualify.

holdings.text: the mere fact of giving joint family property in security for the good conduct of a member of the family employed in a post of trust was sufficient to make the emoluments of the post joint family property because of any detriment to family property or risk of loss.

anchor.surface_text: but the respondents were not able to refer to any decision in which it was held that the mere fact of giving joint family property in security for the good conduct of a member of the family employed in a post of trust was sufficient to make the emoluments of the post joint family property because of any detriment to family property or risk of loss.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No precedent supports security alone creating detriment/risk under HUF income doctrine.

holdings.text: We therefore allow this appeal and set aside the judgment and order of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the judgment of the High Court was erroneous on both questions which were referred to it and they should both have been decided in favour of the appellant. The emoluments received by Sheel Chandra were in the nature of salary and therefore assessable under s. 7 of the Income- tax Act and not under s. 10 of the Act as profits and gains of business and the salary was the income of the individual, i.e., Sheel Chandra and not the income of the Hindu undivided family. We therefore allow this appeal and set aside the judgment and order of the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred on both referred questions.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow this appeal and set aside the judgment and order of the High Court.
